div1.p: Consulate General of the United States Monrovia, Liberia, August 22, 1891
Mr Beverly Y. Payne, To the Department of State.
Consulate General of the United States Monrovia, August 22, 1891
Hon., William F. Wharton, Assistant Secretary of State, Washington, D. C.

Sir: I have the honor respectfully to acknowledge receipt of your Nos 10 & 11, of 18th and 21st : the latter enclosing copy of a letter from Rebecca J. Appleton, and other of the family of Mr Clark, late Minister of the United States at Monrovia.

Your instruction to take the necessary steps to cause the trasnportation of the remains of the deceased Minister, to Muscatine, Iowa, U.S.A, will be caried out as sounds it is safe to do so. Then being no facility of embalmment in Liberia, the remains were interred without, and cannot be exhumed for transportation immediately, but
but may be in these in four months hence.

i thank you for your advice in reference to the shipment of Mr Clark's personal affects, and expense incurred thereby. I had acted in accordance with same prior to Ac receipt as per enclosed copy of my letter to Mr. George W. Appleton, of the 20th ultims. By the last mail I received a certificate of his appointment and commission, Administrator of the Eastate of Minister Clark deceased.
I have the honor to be, Sir, Your obedient Servant,
Beverly Y. Payne U.S. Vice Consul
1. Copy of Mr Payne's to Mr Appleton, July 20th 1891
Consulate General of the United States Monrovia, Liberia, July 20 1891.
Mr George W. Appleton. Muscatine, Iowa.

Dear Sir: I have written you several letters since the death of your Father, and I am, without any in reply. This serves to advise that I shipped all his personal affects to you on the 16th inst., ber Bark "Liberia" in care of Messers Yates & Porterfield, 19, William Street, New York City, to whom, you will make application for same.

I enclose a copy of inventory and two kegs to , which I trust you will find in order. I also enclose six family letters there of which I did not recognize to be from his relatives, hence I opened them. I shall forward the Account at earliest opportunity.
I remain your obd' serv't Beverly Y. Payne U.S. VIce Consul Genl
